results.content: So, ok, we built a blog using rails, ruby, html, css and bootstrap. On the plus side, I got an immersive experience of building something practical using so many different things. So, now, I don't feel that these are strange terms. I got a little bit of the demystifying that I needed. On the negative side, a lot of the course so far focused on the mechanics of getting the cloud9, etc text editors up and running. I am still not clear what is rails, what is ruby, how they are different, why is it called ruby on rails, etc. Now I think this course promises to teach too many things and so skims at the surface level only on each. Overall, it has been ok so far.

results.content: Not a very good course. For the important fundamental web development aspects he just simply sends us to a 3rd party website to learn the material... so why am I paying for this course to be redirected to a place where I can learn the content for FREE!? In the lectures, we just copy his code while he does a poor job of explaining it - most of the time telling us we can just look up the documentation if we want to understand it more. A huge chunk of this "complete" web dev course is him doing a poor job of teaching us how to use rails to complete very specific tasks. There are MUCH (and I mean MUCH) better courses on here (and elsewhere) if you want to learn ruby on rails or take a complete web dev course (I've already enrolled in a lot of others).

results.content:
I gave this course a well earned 5 stars for a few reasons
- The content especially for those starting out is top quality.
- The number of topics covered.
- The fact that you have a project to put on GitHub which these days is very important.
- Finally the instructor himself Rob, you really could not ask for a better and more helpful instructor.

All of the above means that if you have the time and money investing in this course should be a no-brainer.

Skip this one.  Find a current beginner course.

results.content: Robeen Dey gives an excellent explanation of web development with ruby on rails in a very much self-contained course. He will try to explain technical fundamentals by sketching the web development from test to production of an application. The classes are well structured and the mentoring is not improvised. In principle the course is taught assuming no experience whatsoever in web development (actually no experience with programming at all!) but you can easily have a higher programming level with not experience with RoR (like me...) and you will still benefit from course. Robeen technique is simple but effective: if you didn't understand the first videos, don't worry: he will keep repeating and revising many times the same topic in further lessons so you will end up memorising concepts and routines. If you already know some OO programming in any language you will have an advantage and the sections about html, css, JavaScript and ruby will be more for reference. Robeen is very interested in providing an excellent mentoring, being generally available in the discussion board as well as working on improving the content to take you to an advanced level. (In fact, when I wrote this review the first time I gave it 4 stars, but I had to edit after more good content was added!). So: If you are a newbie in web development and your are thinking in RoR as an option, try this course FIRST! And if you didn't know anything about RoR before this course, wait to get to lesson 119: truly a turn-point!

results.content:
**UPDATED Review** This course is fantastic and it definitely does a good job of getting you up to speed on using Ruby on Rails.  The level of effort put into this course is unbelievable and the instructor has done an amazing job keeping up with changes (i.e. changing from Nitrious to the Cloud9 IDE).  The instructor relies alot on free resources that other people have put together to build the bigger picture (which is great) but sometimes it can lead to some inconsistencies in instructional style.

The Software as a Service project that you put together in this course is pretty impressive and very fun, but I feel this is where the course is lacking.  The instructor relies on alot of Gems and technologies and doesn't really talk about how he made the choices for the technologies he is using, why he made those choices, or how you may make those choices on your own.  One phrase that is too often repeated towards the end of the course is "if this doesn't make sense now just..." there is alot happening and if somebody doesn't have alot of development experience it could be very easy to get lost.

Hands down the best addition that could be made to this course (as a bonus/postscript) would be walking through the design of the SaaS site, I think this would really help those who wanted to take this course and use it to build their own company.

All things being said, I've taken MANY online training courses.  I taught myself computer programming at a very young age, and chose this course to see what Rails is all about and it is by far the best online course I've ever taken.

results.content:
This is an excellent course and the teacher is great, but please please please update this course to reflect newer versions and changes. I've run into so many problems, not the least because of Nitrous no longer existing and Cloud9 being taken over by Amazon Web Services.
Cloud9 does not integrate well with Heroku at all, and the gems don't carry over. For example, in development and test, the sqlite3 gem needs to be used, but Heroku does not accept that gem and  can only use pg gem. 
This is not explained clearly in the course and I spent hours trying to figure this out on my own, banging my head against the wall.

I still think this is a great course though and I have already learnt a lot.
results.content_html:

I still think this is a great course though and I have already learnt a lot.

results.content:
I started this week and I'm halfway through my tutorials. I'm still picking up new learnings which I didn't get in my other online tutorials. I actually know HTML and CSS but still went through the lessons just to  check if I am updated with my practices and resources. I will post another review when I complete the course.  Btw, Rob reaches out to students via email and discussion forums and pointing students to resources. I hope he continues to be accessible 3 years later.
UPDATE: 14 days later...
Finished the course! Rob Dey's way of 
explaining is illuminating. The flow of the lectures
builds up to some intensity and then eases, and then
goes beast mode again. 

Ruby on Rails has a steep learning curve and it seems 
impossibly fast how I progressed in this course,
This is because I've spent the last 2 months going
through other Rails tutorials and this by miles, is my favorite
and will be the one I'd recommend.

***
4 months after I've completed my project, I still revisit this tutorial and look out for Rob's updates. He keeps his materials up to date and add supplementary tutorials when some other instructors you won't hear from a month after they launch their lessons.

results.content: I appreciated Rob's demeanor and professional delivery across each lecture. Rob also seems very responsive and happy to help anyone having trouble, or answer a Rails-related question. I signed up for this course already having a solid foundation in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, and already having completed all the assigned Codecademy courses but the one for Rails. I'm thankful for all I've learned so far about RoR. I've actually used Ruby for several years as an automation developer, but I'm pursuing a career in web development, and Rails recently occurred to me as a logical path to take. I also know some PHP/WordPress, but it's not as common for a developer to make a full-time living on that platform. Having finished this program, I'm not in a position yet to dive right into full-time employment using this technology and framework, but Rob definitely has me going in the right direction. Now if I could just think of an idea for a web application of my own...

results.content:
This is a great course that follows along with The Odin Project for the most part. If you got stuck with TOP, or are wanting a pretty thorough intro to web development, this is a good bet. Rob speaks clearly and at length about the basics. The topics are organized well.

I took off a star because of the cloud9/nitrous change in the courses (the videos should be redone), and because the end of the course is mostly just sending you out to other resources.

All in all it is a great intro, not so great intermediate to advanced course. For intermediate to advanced you will need to find a course that focuses on one aspect at a time.

I took off a star because of the cloud9/nitrous change in the courses (the videos should be redone), and because the end of the course is mostly just sending you out to other resources.

All in all it is a great intro, not so great intermediate to advanced course. For intermediate to advanced you will need to find a course that focuses on one aspect at a time.

results.content:
One of the best course I have taken with Udemy and I have taken a lot. It is also complete, not like the other courses I have bought or gotten free.  The instructor speaks very clearly and makes sure you are following him step by step. He will pause and tell you which line he is on, so students will not be lost. Also, he will scroll up and down on his screen slowly, which helped me through the course. In contrast to other instructors, he tells you where he is clicking and placing the code in very detail manner. Other instructors will just place the code in and scroll away leaving student placing the code in the wrong area.  
More importantly, he will explain why he did it and how the code works as the students get deeper into the lessons. He will show you other resources to continue to grow as a developer. He truly cares about his students successfulness unlike other Udemy so call self proclaim instructors. It seem like other instructors that I have taken are creating multiple courses just to make money. 
However, Robeen Dey really wants each student to grow as a developer. Thank you so much putting this course together. If you do decide to put another course together,I will definitely take it. Maybe you can make a course on debugging. A great web developer should know how to debug and find a solution.  Even the answers are online, if the student or web developer does not know how to word the question or send the code over. The answer can not be found....maybe get all the best questions from students or common mistakes... just a suggestion.

results.content:
IN A FEW WORDS:
If you are very determined to learn and have a LOT of patience (to get through confusing videos with a sleepy narator, that you will probably have to watch multiple times to fully understand), then this course will teach you things, but you can find cheaper (or even free) courses, that are WAY better.

IN A LOT OF WORDS:
I got this course in a sale (I think $10) and that was good for the price. While the content in this course will eventually teach you things, I cannot rate it any higher, because of these reasons:

1) Instructor's voice: By far the most annoying thing. It made me so sleepy and feel like he is so bored of what he is saying that sometimes I stopped the videos and did something else. He speaks so slow I had to watch the videos in 2x speed.

2) Lack of explanations: For the biggest part of the course I was in the dark about what I was typing and why. The instructor tries to explain things, but fails to make you pay attention to major information, that will guide you down the line. He just says to keep that in mind and that we will explain something or dive deeper into it down the line, but when you actually get there, you don't remember where you did this before or why. It would be much better to first spend some time explaining things and THEN go put them into practice.

3) Content flow: The flow of the resources provided is backwards... First you follow through with the instructor's confusing train of thought and in the end there is a link to codecademy courses which are waaaaay better in terms of provided information and flow. I realised that doing these courses first and THEN watching the videos of the section, made me understand the content way better. The external resources from codecademy made the videos from that course seem so lacking, that it's funny people pay so much for the course. The instructor also often trails off to explain something minor, but takes 5-6 minutes to get back in course, which was highly annoying. I wish he spent as much time to explain actually useful and important concepts.

results.content: I have been at this Ruby on Rails thing for quite some time as a self-directed learner and getting a job at it is not easy. It seems like employers will consider you for other programming jobs but for Ruby they seem to be very strict and no after finishing this course you will not be marketable. This course says you could get a job with HashRocket. I have tried and they told me they see me as an apprentice and they are not hiring apprentices at this time. By the way I have over five production level Ruby apps and I am currently working on number six, plus I have done collaborations with colleagues, so you see what I mean?

results.content: This is a great course especially the Ruby on Rails Dev Match project part! I've learned a ton from this course and the instructor is very attentive and will give you quick feedback if you have a question (extremely valuable)! Will look forward to what this instructor puts out next. Some constructive criticism for the instructor IMHO: at least for me I tend to watch a lot of the lectures right in a row, so it can be a little redundant if you don't pick up where you left off and have to cd back into your workspace/project everytime. I can understand this for the first few lectures of course for people who don't quite have the hang of it yet though. The other thing I would do is scrap that intro to every lecture, its a little annoying. Just a few little suggestions to make the pace of the course a little faster. Other than that I loved it, thank you! Quick note too, I would LOVE to see a lecture added on how to integrate AWS to host the paperclip images. I am having a VERY hard time with it and actually ended up having to scrap the whole project and start over because I messed everything up so bad trying to integrate AWS.

results.content:
I was very excited about taking this course. I am a little discouraged after joining in on this course; simply not what I was looking for. 
Clearly, Robeen knows the subject. Unfortunately, it doesn't come across that way thru the video lectures. I found myself constantly looking around for answers. The most annoying issue is that fact that the lessons are not consistent. It starts early too. Migrating from Nitrous to cloud9 was wasted time. The lack of explanation as too what we were doing in our IDE was aggravating. Far to many generalities, this is the "file system", yet it includes dozens of files that are also "very important"...come'on man! 
            Beginning with Ruby is also a bust. I figured starting with front end then move to back end dev. then finish off honing full stack skills. Maybe it simply wasn't for me, but as an iOS developer working with Obj - C and Swift Its possible I have expectations when it comes to web dev. I guess I was wrong.
I think the best thing about this course right now is the fact that I am getting a refund.

results.content:
My only complaint would be that I'm too lazy to read books or I would have done that instead.  I want to watch videos. Since I have to look stuff up and read while I'm learning all the stuff you can't teach me, I suppose I should just get over it!

The instruction is great!  The only recommendation I have would be how to troubleshoot misbehaving gems in the Ruby on Rails tutorials.  It's a great program, but there is always something that goes wrong.  Because of that, you have to READ... all the documentation, go through StackOverflow (which can be a mistake sometimes), go through all the forums to make sure it hasn't already been solved and basically work with alternatives until you get it right.

In the process of all of this, you will learn a LOT!!  There is so much information in this course (without the above-mentioned research) that going through it in 12 weeks is tough.  But, this course sets you up for success.  You are not going to be disappointed!

First person to finish this course, had 1 consultation  with Rob on Skype since then heard nothing so much for helping students find work Rob. Please don't bother contacting me after you read my review update im not interested.
I have seen other courses on the ruby on rails subject but have to say what Rob has prepared in this course blow's everything else away. The patience he shows in explaining each individual parts that makes the applications work is amazing, his instruction is clear and his voice is easy on the ears which has been a big let-down in other courses I have followed not being able to understand what the tutor is saying. 
175 lectures is not for the faint hearted, but nothing in life is easy if you want to be successful. So I have no problem recommending this course to anyone don’t waste your money elsewhere jump on board with Rob as I believe he is the best tutor I have seen on Udemy and this guy definitely knows what he’s talking about.  
If you’d like to speak with me about my honest review or are still undecided about jumping on board this course please don’t hesitate to contact me directly through Udemy, and just for the record this is the first course I have followed of Rob’s and have never met him.

results.content:
You are not majoring in computer science and try to learn web development skills?  Complete this course first, and then deep dive in any further courses such as Javascript, node.js, or even iOS app development.

This will give you such a full-milestoned picture of whole development process, how the front and server side communicate together, how each UI is built and working properly.   However, this course does not dig in out more about each concept because it is just a bootcamp course.   If you expect to have something advanced class that makes you more expert, this is not your course.  If you are a first-starter and want to know the whole picture, and then want to learn more deep level on each concept, this is the best course for you.

The course is outdated. The structure is good and the creator explains well the basics you need to start the projects. And then it is a disaster. You have to use so many different services, some of them are no longer available, others have significant differences that you can't configure and at the end you give up. It's really a shame that this course is still offered by Udemy. I strongly recommend you NOT to buy it!

UPDATE: After i completed the course, i still don't recommend this course, as it is outdated. If you want to dive in Ruby on Rails, implementing a simple yet comprehensive project, then you could try your patience finishing it. But in case you are interested in Javascript and other modern frameworks (NodeJS, AngulaJS etc.) you should look for other course.

results.content:
I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in learning Ruby and Rails.  Here's my summary.

THE GOOD
Rob is a fantastic teacher and is still involved in the discussions on the sidebar when people has issues. He responds to things on a daily basis. He's also great at breaking down the complex concepts and repeats those things often throughout the course. Even if you get lost, just press on and the later lectures will REALLY help you understand what's going on.

Also, Rob includes all the code and instructions lesson by lesson and even lets you download the entire source. This is invaluable. For me, it is often easier to paste code and really sit there and stare at the screen as he enters his code and explains things.  It's often too distracting if you're trying to "keep up" or pause the screen to fix syntax errors.  Obviously you could copy/paste and not learn a thing, but if you're willing to take the time and pay attention, you'll learn a ton.

THE BAD
Just know that Rob will not be the one teaching you most of the coding.  The necessary homework is going to often send you to the free courses at CodeAcademy where you will spend days learning all the syntax in a very frustrating environment and you will spend a large amount of time trying to figure out why you entered proper code and it didn't work.  It sucks. Unfortunately, that's where the bulk of the Ruby learnin' actually comes from.

UNDERSTAND
You can go to CodeAcademy and take that stuff for free without buying this course. What you're paying Rob for is his excellent step by step walkthrough on how to build a fully functioning Ruby on Rails Application.

ALSO UNDERSTAND
This course has a large expectation that you are going to use additional outside resources (sometimes at additional expense) to fully learn the important concepts this class wants you to learn.   So you will spend 25% of the total time learning from Rob, 25% of the time beating your head against a wall at Code Academy and 50% of your time going through the resources at the end of the class to get the full experience.  

Is it worth it? Yes.  Just know what you're getting yourself into.
Thanks Rob!

results.content:
The content is certainly great, the lecturer seems to know his stuff. I would say, though, that he does end up sounding quite monotonous after a few lessons. He tends to repeat the basics over and over again, which is probably good for some students, but I imagine others will grow tired of it pretty quick. 

Additionally, the instructor sends students off to Codeacademy to do some further learning for the course material (so far, HTML and CSS), and frankly, I found Codeacademy far better for my learning style than this course - the material there is delivered in small bite sized chunks, with lots of practical hands-on work in the subject matter.
